body:

author: CannaVestments
body:
Pretty sure it took TER about a month to accomplish what RWB did in 1 year+ in getting pre-qualification for a Michigan acquisition lol 

https://www.globenewswire.com/en/news-release/2021/05/27/2237690/0/en/Red-White-Bloom-Brands-Announces-Successful-Pre-Qualification-in-the-State-of-Michigan.html

author: Trisolaran_arbitrage
body: I like Teradyne (semiconductor testing equipment), Illumina (genetic sequencing equipment and kits), and United Rentals (renting construction equipment to contractors and developers) for these reasons. Construction is not quite a fast up-and-coming industry, but with the infrastructure package possibly coming I think they are a good play.

author: graham2100
body:
In the very long term terrible investors probably regress to the mean, i.e. index funds, except (i) when they go broke sooner and (ii) at higher costs than your typical Vanguard TER. 

Value investors may recognize their is no need to be invested all of the time. Buffett currently keeps large amounts of cash not seeing anything of value.

author: [deleted]
body: Yes, that, absolutely nothing to do with the NFL starting Thursday or the massive ESPN partnership about to be announced. DE-REK JE-TER

author: CannaVestments
body:
Unfortunately at this point there aren't many licenses left to buy as most are owned by public operators. GTI/Verano/Acreagw/TER/CC/AWH/AYR/Cura are 8 of the  12, Ianthus likely trying to hold theirs, Jusrice Grown (private MSO) likely not an option, not sure of the other 2 but I bet everyone approached them to sell. There has been several dozen (I figure the exact number) licenses held up in court since 2019 so perhaps they are waiting on those as well. 

Still time but a head start helps a lot

author: poopANDweed
body: I would say this is a good premium for Gage. It’s a stock deal and TER stock has been crushed since they said they will miss their 2021 forecast. The reason TERs stock tanked is a short term problem (lower yields/quality due to grow expansion), so Gage actually got a pretty good deal relative to where the two stocks were trading a month ago.

author: trilogee
body: Ter and gage both halted. Very likely to be a buyout announcement.

author: Mister_Rahool
body: Can someone explain to me why GAGE is doing nothing and TER is slightly down with the buy being a 17% premium on current prices?

author: Zannierer
body:
1. Dragon Capital picked the right time to introduce E1VFVN30 though. The last 5 years did saw very serious double digit gains, but the 5 years before it were stagnant, hence lower than expected decade gains. However this could still be a good sign for what to come, if all those reports on Vietnamese market being undervalued is right.

2. You're right, I need to look past the crashes, but the market is still young so that's an addtional risk.

3. I've read that larger NAV correlates with lower TER and it seems to be the case for the mentioned ETFs. 

Anyway, thanks for the input.

author: mr_molecular
body: To play the arbitrage, people short TER and buy GAGE. As long as the deal closes, they will earn the 15% arb, regardless of what price TER is at when the deal finalizes. It will probably take nearly 6 months to finalize, 15% in 6 months isn't bad, but there may be better opportunities.

author: NiamorJafar
body: TER and Gage halted.   Very interesting.

author: trilogee
body: I wasn't aware that Linton was even involved in TER? As far as I know his only involvement was inking the deal with CGC and ter at the time but no current involvement/position right? Jw is the bigger and obvious connection. I'll eat my tshirt if this isn't an m&a announcement

author: mr_molecular
body:
Usually 3 to 4 months, since there will be no complicated issues integrating Gage, which only has assets in Michigan into TER; which does not have any Michigan assets.

Cresco/Bluma took 3 months plus another week or so for the shares to actually convert.

author: wet_tree
body:
It’s a strong buy IMO. 
The gage and TER connection is incredibly bullish, the lakers is incredibly bullish, and whatever the hell storz & Bickel keynote is about I am keenly interested in. 

I wouldn’t worry about share price. If it was unique to CGC I’d worry but it’s not. 

Cash burn is better, market share is stabilizing. I see more upside than down. 

So many hurdles for some of these younger companies to navigate thru. CGC is cashed up and have a lot of their chess pieces still in play. 

There are pros and cons to everything, and you may prefer how others operate, but when you stack it all up I like the vision. 

2¢

author: wabty
body: Double dipping on the TER. Clever!

author: Mister_Rahool
body: right just surprised by the lack of volatility, TER giving up 1/3rd the company like HEXO

body:

author: jeffreynoyes001
body: The people who profited most from the gold rush in the 1800s weren’t the miners themselves, but rather the individuals who supplied the equipment. I like Teradyne a lot, which supplies automatic test equipment for chips and has an assortment of the big names as customers. They’re also building up their robotics businesses.

author: crazyhiit
body:
HOOD - 90%  
ROKU - 3%  
DOCU - 3%  
TER - 2%  
ZS - 2%

Am I screwed because of that 90%?

author: cicator
body: Fuck the bank, I would bet they try to sell you their own fonds with a ter of 2%. Just go with a low cost world etf.
